channel.title: Question about Trademarks and Legal Information
channel.description: Hey guys, I was just wondering. Let’s say you upload a track on SoundCloud under some alias. What if a person has the same alias and discovers that you allegedly “used” theirs? Do they have the right to sue you? Or do you have the right to sue them?

item.title: Question about Trademarks and Legal Information
item.dc:creator: akabillposters
item.description:
TXA:

Do they have the right to sue you? Or do you have the right to sue them?

Whoever has precedence (who demonstrably used it first) would be the one able to sue - but typically* only if they’ve actually registered it as a trademark.

* If they’re just using it as an unregistered trademark, then they would only stand a chance of being able to sue you if they’d been using it for a long time and had built up substantial recognition within the same industry and audience - to the point where the audience might reasonably assume music released under that name to have come from them.

 
(You don’t need to register a trademark to use the ™ symbol. A properly registered trademark often appears with the ® symbol. Registration give some you legal protection against copiers, though generally only within the same or closely related industries.)

Read full topic
item.source: Question about Trademarks and Legal Information

item.title: Question about Trademarks and Legal Information
item.dc:creator: Little_Baby
item.description:
You should talk to them and try to figure out a way to work it out. Maybe Make a minor adjustment, such as changing the o to a zero, or something like that, rather than sue them, if Voltt as it’s own is Not trademarked.

Read full topic
item.source: Question about Trademarks and Legal Information
